title: Mysterious debris balls wash up on NSW beaches again
text:
Debris balls have washed up on several NSW ﻿beaches again, but authorities are unsure whether they are related to the ones that were previously found along dozens of Sydney beaches.

The Central Coast Council confirmed the balls were found at The Entrance Beach, Grant McBridge Baths, Blue Bay, Toowoon Bay, North Shelly Beach, Shelly Beach and Blue Lagoon Beach.

The Grant McBride Baths have been temporarily shut.

Debris balls have washed up on several beaches on NSW's Central Coast. (Central Coast Council )

Beachgoers are advised to avoid going to the affected sites and not to touch the debris.

The debris balls are grey-coloured, ranging in size from one to four centimetres.

﻿The NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA) was first notified by a beachgoer who stumbled upon the balls at North Shelly Beach.

Council has since cleared all visible balls from that beach. ﻿﻿

Samples have been collected for testing, but the composition and source of the material are not yet known and could be from a variety of sources, like stormwater, sewerage or ships.

According to council, it is unclear whether these debris balls are related to the ones that washed up on Sydney beaches from October to January.﻿

Investigations and clean-up are currently ongoing.

Council is managing the matter, but the EPA has offered to help if needed. ﻿

"Council also advised they will continue monitoring beaches and will send samples of the debris balls for testing," an EPA spokesperson said. ﻿

"Further actions will be considered once test results are received."

READ MORE: ﻿ Major dam expected to spill 15 billion litres a day after huge rain

The debris balls could be from a variety of sources, like stormwater, sewerage or ships. ﻿ (Central Coast Council )

Black-coloured debris balls first appeared in Coogee, in Sydney's east, in October before dozens more started popping up along the coastline up until January. ﻿

The EPA investigated and found the likely source of these balls was Sydney Water's land-based sewage treatment network.

The definite source ﻿still has not been determined.

title: King of medieval 'Woodstock' explains enduring appeal of Dark Ages
text:
As a boy growing up in Scotland, Alpin Grant dreamed of being a knight.

The idea took root as he watched a Viking ship run aground on the shores of Arbroath, at a medieval festival.

"These guys … jump out of the ship, have a fight in the water and on the beaches," he recalled.

"Then they would drag the boat up to be burned later that night."

Alpin Grant attended medieval festivals as a boy in Scotland. (Supplied: Alpin Grant)

The re-enactment lit a fire in him and, unlike most people who shed their childhood fantasies as they get older, Mr Grant leaned in.

By day, the 32-year-old works for a mining company in Western Australia, but the rest of the time, he can be found doing "medieval things" and running the South West's only medieval social group with his wife, Laura.

The Kingdom of Athera meets weekly on their farm in Dardanup, south of Perth, which has a fighting arena, a tavern and a mead hall.

The group specialises in sword combat, leather crafting, painting, woodcarving, brewing and blacksmithing.

"I always say it takes a special kind of stupid to get in the ring and hit each other with swords," he said.

"It's the passion that comes with it — you get to live out your kid fantasy of being a knight in shining armour and hitting each other.

"And I provide a space for that. It's really my thing."

Alpin Grant has embraced the medieval scene in WA since moving from Scotland. (ABC South West WA: Bridget McArthur)

Mr Grant is under no illusions about the historical realities of Dark Ages living, but relishes being able to "pick and choose the best bits".

"There is nothing more adrenaline pumping than hearing that sword clang right in front of your face," he said.

"Smelling that burning steel two inches from your nose and knowing that could have been my head if I didn't block that."

The Grants were brought together by their mutual fascination with the Dark Ages and have since been crowned King Wülfhammer and Queen Revna of the annual Balingup Medieval Carnivale.

They were originally approached by the festival committee to help breathe new life into the event, which is now in its 30th year and features market stalls, sparring, archery and a blazing dragon.

Loading...

"I said I'd do it on the condition that I got to be king. I thought that was a pretty good deal," he said.

" People usually ask me if I'm a real knight. Well not really, but in this world, yeah, sure I am. "

'Woodstock of medieval festivals'

Ros Benson started the Balingup Medieval Carnivale in 1995, and has seen it grow from a small, "quirky" festival for locals to a major celebration.

"It was just an event for Balingup to celebrate our creativity and wackiness," she said.

"Now it's probably the biggest income earner for Balingup."

The Balingup Medieval Carnivale is known for its "quirkiness". (ABC South West WA: Bridget McArthur)

Ms Benson said local residents were still the beating heart of the festival, something she is keen to preserve.

"Because we're such a little town it means everybody who is able is volunteering," she said.

"We can't get too much bigger without growing to a bigger town ourselves, which we don't really want."

Mr Grant said the carnival was the "benchmark" event and people planned their yearly costumes around it.

"The effort that goes in is sometimes astonishing," he said.

" It's basically our Woodstock. It's pretty much the event of the year for us medieval enthusiasts. "

Alpin Grant says some people plan their yearly costumes around the Balingup Medieval Carnivale. (ABC South West WA: Bridget McArthur)

In an era where the nine-to-five grind dominates most people's day-to-day lives, Mr Grant said the festival was a source of escapism and camaraderie.

He said he had been particularly pleased to see more young people joining in.

"Groups of teenagers, young adolescents [are] just going out for the day and getting out there, enjoying something new and exciting with their friends," he said.

"It's a nice breath of fresh air … something so flamboyant, drums and loud costumes and all of that does wake you up."

title: Storm skipper Grant suspended as Bunker drama leaves Dogs puzzled
text:
The imminent return of Jahrome Hughes has been soured by the suspension of Storm captain Harry Grant, who faces an enforced two-week break after Melbourne's hard-fought win over Canterbury.

The Storm moved four points clear of the third-placed Bulldogs on the back of the 20-14 victory in Melbourne, with Canberra in the box seat to claim the minor premiership after downing Penrith in golden point earlier on Friday.

On Saturday morning, skipper Grant was given a three-week suspension, reduced to two weeks with an early plea, for a shoulder charge on Canterbury's Harry Hayes.

Melbourne still has two tough top-eight encounters to complete its regular season. The Storm host the Sydney Roosters next Friday night before a Thursday clash against the Broncos in Brisbane.

But with their points difference 144 better than the Bulldogs, they would need to suffer two monumental losses to lose their top-two spot.

Jahrome Hughes has not played since suffering a shoulder injury against the Roosters on July 24. (AAP: Dan Himbrechts)

Cameron Munster has carried a heavy load in recent weeks with his halves partner Hughes sidelined after a shoulder dislocation.

Initially forecast to return in week one of the finals, Hughes is confident about being available for the Broncos match as he continues his rehabilitation on his shoulder that he hurt against the Roosters in late July.

The Storm have only had their first-choice spine on the park for eight matches this season, with fullback Ryan Papenhuyzen also missing a number of games through injury.

"I don't think he needs to play as far as combinations and things like that, but just, I suppose, for his confidence, and having confidence in the shoulder," Bellamy said of Hughes.

"I'd hate for him to go into a final with a bit of doubt.

"So if we could take that doubt out of it by playing him in our last round, we'll look to do that, as long as the physios and the medical people think he's 100 per cent right to play."

Ciraldo questions Bunker ruling after disallowed try

Bulldogs coach Cameron Ciraldo voiced his frustrations after the loss to the Storm following a disallowed try to Stephen Crichton.

The Bulldogs captain thought he had scored in the final minute off a Matt Burton bomb, but the Bunker ruled it to be a knock-on, chalking off the try.

"The whole kick contest again, that's really confusing. You touch him when they're in the air and it's a penalty and then you're allowed to put your arm out and stop them going for a catch," Ciraldo said regarding the incident.

"I actually don't know. I don't get a great look at it but I'll probably send it in [to the NRL] during the week.

Stephen Crichton thought he had gotten the Bulldogs in position to level the scores in the dying seconds before being denied by the Bunker. (Getty Images: Graham Denholm)

"I sent a heap in last week and it doesn't really help, but at least we can try and educate our players on what you're actually looking for, I suppose."

Despite the disallowed try, Crichton was impressed by his side's performance.

"It will give us confidence coming back if we do end up coming back here and playing the first semi-final here," the burly centre said.

"There's so many lessons that we can take out of it, but the bright side is we know that we can go up against the top four teams and have a chance of winning, and it means as a footy team we can get together and believe that as well."

AAP/ABC

title: Record gold price spurs renaissance of 'super' 3,500km tunnel mine
text:
From the public viewing platform overlooking Kalgoorlie's Super Pit gold mine, Greg Hewitt reflects on a four-decade career as an underground miner.

He spent 25 years lugging around a heavy rock drill, known as an air-leg, chasing rich gold deposits at what was once considered the richest square mile on Earth.

The 80-year-old calls it a "dying trade" due to the difficult, dangerous nature of the work and the "calculated risks" he took every day.

"There are plenty of blokes in the cemetery … they would be in stunned disbelief," he said of the 4.5 kilometre-long, 1.5km-wide and 600 metre-deep Super Pit, which is so big it is visible from space.

"They just wouldn't believe the effort and time that's been put in for that elusive bit of gold … I didn't think it [the Super Pit] would last, no way mate."

Loading...

As a teenager, Mr Hewitt got his start in the surveying office at the Lake View and Star mine on Kalgoorlie's famous Golden Mile.

Generations of miners like "Pecker", as he is affectionately known, apparently due to a "large nose", have worked the ground since 1893.

"In 1965, a fellow miner got killed by a slab of rock and I replaced him," he said.

" The shift boss came along and said, 'Hey, young Pecker — do you want to go on the air-leg?' I said, 'Oh shit yeah', because I'd been learning off a few of the older blokes. "

Greg Hewitt worked for decades as an air-leg miner but says it is a dying trade. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

It was hard work, lugging the more than 30-kilogram drill and other equipment up and down ladders and over rocks in stifling underground conditions.

Mr Hewitt worked at Lake View and Star from 1961 to 1970, a period when Australia swapped the pound for a decimal currency and the gold price was fixed at $31.25 an ounce, before it was freely floated in 1971.

After switching to nickel mining when low gold prices shut all but one mine, he returned for another two years on the North Kalgurli mine from 1984.

"Nickel saved a lot of the miners their jobs … the Golden Mile was kaput," he said.

The fortunes of both commodities have flipped again, with WA's nickel industry collapsing and gold prices trading at record highs above $5,000 an ounce, ensuring the Golden Mile enjoys another renaissance.

A miner at work in 1961 at the North Kalgurli mine on the Golden Mile. (Supplied: National Archives of Australia)

History of Golden Mile

According to the Eastern Goldfields Historical Society, the history of the Golden Mile dates back to August 30, 1893, when prospectors William Brookman and Samuel Pearce rode into Coolgardie to register the Great Boulder lease.

They were acting for a South Australian syndicate, and during the remainder of 1893, the pair went on to peg and register a total of 19 leases.

The term Golden Mile became popular around 1899 and was originally used to describe the mines on the Ivanhoe, Great Boulder, Golden Horseshoe, Chaffers, Hannan's Star and Boulder Main Reef leases.

Haul trucks operating in Kalgoorlie's Super Pit gold mine. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

In the 1980s, the late Perth magnate Alan Bond launched a buying spree to consolidate ownership of the Golden Mile leases via a complex series of deals.

By 1989, Kalgoorlie Consolidated Gold Mines (KCGM) had been formed to mine the Super Pit, then under a joint venture between Homestake and Normandy Mining.

By 1992, Mr Bond was Australia's biggest bankrupt and the former America's Cup hero was later jailed.

Since open-pit mining began, the Super Pit has swallowed many of the old workings, which comprise more than 3,500km of underground tunnels and shafts.

The Mt Charlotte mine with the massive Super Pit waste stockpiles in the background. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Pit wall failure fixed

In 2017, KCGM — then under ownership of Canada's Barrick Gold and American giant Newmont — poured its 20 millionth ounce of gold.

But barely a year later and the future of the Super Pit was in jeopardy after two separate rockfall incidents totalling more than 1 million tonnes.

Hindsight shows the wall failure was a catalyst to bring the Super Pit into full Australian ownership for the first time in its history.

In late 2019 and early 2020, Saracen Mineral Holdings and then Northern Star Resources bought 50 per cent shares for more than $1.1 billion each.

After less than a year of joint ownership, in which they committed to a cutback to remediate the east wall, the companies completed a $16 billion merger in early 2021.

Simon Jessop says it took 55 months to remediate the Super Pit east wall failure. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Northern Star's chief operating officer Simon Jessop said more than 35 million tonnes were mined during the east wall remediation, which took 55 months until it was completed this year.

"It was the catalyst for the sale and ultimately, we've just opened up the next decades of mining, so it's massively significant," he said.

"This mine will be going beyond 2050 … in 50 years' time, KCGM will still be in operation.

"It might be a different operation, it could be a bigger pit again or it could be the underground growth … that's where we see huge life."

Nick Strong in front of Fimiston Mill, which is set to be commissioned next year. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Expansion nearly complete

According to Melbourne-based gold consultancy Surbiton Associates, the best year on record for the Super Pit was 2011, when the mine produced 796,000 ounces.

The mine's peak production for a single quarter was in the March 2010 quarter, with production of 206,000 ounces.

But Northern Star, which ranks as Australia's biggest gold miner and banked a $1.4 billion net profit last financial year, is eyeing off a much bigger prize.

By this time next year, the company plans to turn on its new Fimiston Mill after a three-year, $1.5 billion project to replace the old plant, which has churned out gold bars since 1989.

Nick Strong has been overseeing the three-year, $1.5 billion upgrade to Fimiston Mill. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

About 600 construction workers have been on site during peak periods, with the new plant to more than double the processing capacity from 12 million tonnes a year currently to 27 million tonnes a year.

"We know we've got a 30-year mine life ahead of us, or thereabouts, so we're building this plant for the next 30 years — it's a high-quality build," KCGM general manager Nick Strong said.

Post-commissioning, the Super Pit is forecast to hit production rates of 900,000 ounces a year during the 2028–29 financial year, and then maintain that rate for the next 10 years.

That would ensure the Super Pit reclaims its crown as Australia's biggest-producing gold mine, currently held by the Boddington mine in WA's South West after producing 574,000 ounces last financial year.

The way Northern Star intends to achieve unprecedented production rates is by drawing on 144 million tonnes of low-grade ore stockpiles, which are estimated to contain $10 billion of gold at current prices.

Seven new underground portals have been cut inside the Super Pit. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Heading back underground

Mining of the Golden Mile has now come full circle, heading back below the surface since the first underground access portal was established on the western wall of the Super Pit in 2021.

Another seven portals, named after old mining leases such as Croesus, Union Jack and Drysdale, have been installed in the past 12 months.

Underground exploration is cheaper than drilling deeper holes from the surface, with geologists finding more than 1.2 million ounces in the past year alone.

Of the estimated 14.4 million ounces of reserves yet to be mined at KCGM, 8.3 million ounces are in the open pit and 3.2 million ounces are from underground sources.

Daniel Howe says new underground drilling platforms will allow testing for extensions. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Northern Star's chief geologist Daniel Howe said some of the areas drilled have never been tested, despite more than a century of mining.

"As we've drilled those areas, we've identified a number of new lodes we didn't know about," he said.

"Obviously there's a big future at the south for the pit, but we certainly see the opportunity in the northern area being underground … and there's plenty more to be had with further drilling."

Geologist Gemma Leftley and mining engineer Brianna Reid. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Nine drill rigs are currently turning underground at the Super Pit and the adjacent Mt Charlotte mine, which has been operating continuously since 1963.

"We've currently got about nine rigs operating around the clock," geologist Gemma Leftley said.

"At the end of the 2026 financial year, we're probably looking at 14."

It speaks to the level of exploration investment, which this financial year is budgeted at $48 million, while long-term there are plans to realign a 25km-long section of the Trans Australian Railway Line around the Super Pit.

"We believe there's geological continuity … so move the railway and I'll tell you how much gold's there," Northern Star's managing director Stuart Tonkin quipped.

Stuart Tonkin says the Super Pit is being set up for the next 30 years. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Miner has no regrets

It is part of a strong belief by many that there is plenty of gold left to be found near the historic Golden Mile, where Mr Hewitt is "bloody proud" of his contribution.

But it came at a significant personal cost.

Many friends died on the job, and there was forced early retirement at 58 with two steel knees, a reconstructed shoulder and severe neck pain evidence of a life on the tools.

Greg Hewitt spent more than a decade as a miner on Kalgoorlie's Golden Mile. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

"We went hell for leather every moment of the day," he said.

"When you got out of the cage, you would throw your crib bag up where the cockroaches couldn't get at it and away you'd go to do your job."

He recalls old miners' folklore about a secret tunnel to the cellar of the Boulder Block Hotel, which was famously sold for a reported $7 million to make way for the Super Pit's expansion.

The other part of that folklore was miners would exchange stolen gold for cash or beer.

"But I wouldn't know anything about that, cobber — that's just what I was told," he said.

Greg Hewitt has become a keen prospector since retiring from mining. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

This year's record gold prices have spurred on Australia's big gold miners and small prospectors like Mr Hewitt.

Just before leaving the Super Pit lookout, he reached into his wallet and pulled out a small nugget shaped like a rabbit.

"And this is what they're chasing," he said with a big grin.

"I could tell you where I found it, but then I'd have to kill you."

title: 'She's beautiful': New Spirit of Tasmania ferry arrives in Hobart
text:
One of the new Spirit of Tasmania ships has arrived in Hobart, but it is more than a year away from being ready to ferry passengers and freight between Tasmania and Victoria.

Spirit of Tasmania IV and V have greater capacity for passengers and vehicles than the two aging ships currently in operation.

Spirit IV arrived in Hobart today following a 27,515-kilometre voyage from Scotland, where it had been docked since the completion of construction in Finland.

Spirit of Tasmania IV will have a final fit-out done while in Hobart. (ABC News)

While in Hobart, the ships will undergo a final fit-out, which will include Tasmanian-made mattresses, tabletops and artwork.

The Tasmanian government said Spirit V would remain in Finland until November, when it will need to be moved to another location in Europe to avoid sea ice in Finland.

The government said the ship would then head to Tasmania in the first half of next year for a final fit-out.

Spirit of Tasmania IV has arrived in Hobart from Finland. (Supplied)

Celebration in Devonport for Spirit IV's arrival

The new ships require a bigger dock, which is currently being built in Devonport.

But construction is not expected to be completed until October 2026, meaning the ships cannot operate until then.

Spirit IV near Devonport's Mersey Bluff on its way to Hobart. (ABC News: Meg Fergusson)

On its way to Hobart on Friday afternoon, Spirit IV stopped off the coast of its future home.

Locals from across north-west Tasmania flocked to Devonport to see the ship.

"It's costing us so much money and it's come so far, that we really hope it will lift our state and bring plenty of visitors in and pay for itself," Chresley Elphinstone said.

" It's been a shambles, really, but I just hope they've got it all right now — but that port should have been ready a long time ago. "

Kerry Morgan and Chresley Elphinstone of Wynyard watched Spirit IV sail past Devonport. (ABC News: Meg Fergusson)

'Hurricane-force' winds caused new Spirit ships to come loose Photo shows Spirit V resting against tugboat Severe winds have caused one of the two new Spirit of Tasmania vessels to break loose from its outfitting quay at a shipyard in Finland, but the extent of damage is yet to be determined.

Devonport Mayor Alison Jarman was ecstatic to finally see the ship.

"She's beautiful," she said.

"To see her come out of the mist and be real and for everyone to have a bit of ownership now to say 'she's ours.'"

For Ms Jarman, it was a bright moment amid the political turmoil.

"There's been a lot of angst over the drama of the Spirits," she said.

"This is a real positive, the people are here to celebrate that beautiful ship that is going to make a huge difference to Tasmania."

" Everyone's here, it's a party. "

Spirit IV will not be operational until a new berth in Devonport is ready, which is expected to be in October next year. (ABC News: Meg Fergusson)

Spirit of Tasmania IV ferry arrives in Scotland Photo shows A news anchorwoman at the start of a package on the Spirit of Tasmania with the words 'Ferry Fiasco' behind her. It'll cost at least $47,534 a week, plus costs, for the Spirit of Tasmania IV to berth in Scotland under a 30-day deal struck by the Tasmanian government.

The bungled rollout has caused political turmoil in Tasmania, with the infrastructure minister who oversaw the project losing his job over it.

It was also one of the reasons listed by the Labor opposition for moving a no-confidence motion in Premier Jeremy Rockliff, which led the state to an early election that ultimately saw the re-election of the Liberal government.

Loading...

Ship 'beautifully' handled rough journey to Australia

Rear Admiral Steve Gilmore, one of the directors of TT-Line, spoke to the ABC over the phone from Spirit of Tasmania IV.

"We had a real test of the ship and its sea-keeping as we came across the Great Australian Bight in winter," he said.

"She handled it beautifully."

From Spirit IV, he watched crowds come out in Devonport to catch a glimpse of the ship.

"What we can see through binoculars is cars parked everywhere, and that's just fantastic," he said.

"Very excited about bringing this ship home."

Spirit of Tasmania IV docked in Fremantle en route to Tasmania. (Supplied: TT-Line)

The government has been trying since 2017 to build the new ships, which were initially slated for completion in 2021.

Amid the delays, costs have skyrocketed. The Devonport berth was originally costed at $90 million but has blown out to $493 million.

Because the new berth was not ready when the construction of Spirit IV finished, it had to be stored in Scottland — costing Tasmania $4.3 million as of April, which includes fuel, crew and port costs.

title: England 'will get better' after scoring 11 tries in World Cup opener
text:
England might have scored almost 70 points in thrashing the United States in the Women's Rugby World Cup opener, but coach John Mitchell warned there was much more to come from his top-ranked team.

Host nation England's women lived up to their top billing in an 11-try performance, scoring seven of them after the break to win 69-7 over the US in front of a record crowd at Sunderland's Stadium of Light.

They went over for their first try inside the opening 10 minutes and were comfortably 28-7 ahead at the break, but Mitchell said he asked for more.

"We challenged them around lifting the intensity in the second half, and I thought we lifted it well," he told reporters.

The Americans did not get close to the England try line after the break as wave after wave of home attack emphasised why they are the team to beat at the tournament.

Their forward play was powerful, and their backs showed plenty of pace and skill.

"There is a common saying in rugby that a 'forward decides who's going to win the match, and the backs decide by how much,' and I think the forwards definitely took that approach today in their stride," said winger Abby Dowd, who scored one of the 11 tries.

"The key to a successful team is a platform, and the forwards provided us with that," she added.

Ominously, former All Blacks coach Mitchell warned: "There is so much growth to come. We will get better. The tournament will get harder, but we have so much left in us."

The margin of victory, plus the standard of play, will have thrilled the 42,723-strong crowd, which surpassed the previous record of 42,579 at the last World Cup final in Auckland, where England last lost a game.

"The girls got to experience a brilliant home crowd," said Mitchell.

"It's only the first game. We have set a standard, but also the fans have set a standard, and that is something that we are going to rise to and get bigger and better," added fullback Ellie Kildunne, who scored two tries and won the best player award.

"It's a really good start, and it is just the start," she said.

Reuters

title: ABC Quote Quiz: Who said it, and what were they on about?
text:
They said it. We published it. Can you guess it?

This week, we farewelled a film star, revisited an Aussie banger and had a close encounter on a golf course.

From the jaw-dropping to the eyebrow-raising to the mildly confusing, here are some of the best quotes in the news this week.

title: Football star returns to field after tackling rare autoimmune disorder
text:
At one point, Cameron Vazzoler was recognised as the best rugby league player in regional New South Wales.

Having won the best and fairest award in the Group 7 Rugby League competition in 2018, the Kiama Knights halfback was named the Country Player of the Year in 2019.

But just three years later, at the age of 24, his career seemed over after the shock diagnosis of rare autoimmune disorder, Guillain-Barre syndrome.

"It's a neurological disorder which basically [is] your immune system attacking your nerves which causes in mild cases weakness of the muscles, and in severe cases being paralysed," Vazzoler said.

Cameron Vazzoler moved to Bega after winning a title in 2019. (Supplied: Kiama Knights)

" I was in hospital for a week or so, and once I got out of there, I was in a wheelchair. "

For the next 18 months he not only stopped playing football but also had to learn to walk again.

A unique comeback

The diagnosis was shattering for a man used to winning premierships.

Cameron Vazzoler raises the premiership shield in 2022. (Supplied: Bega Roosters)

He played a starring role in breaking Kiama's 34-year Group 7 First Grade title drought in 2019, then moved to Bega in search of more success.

He led that club to its first title in eight years in 2022, before confronting the reality that his career might be over.

"It's such a rare and unique disorder, so there was not too much information on it," he said.

"It was hard to get clear answers off physios and doctors on how long the recovery would be because it was such a unique thing.

"Obviously being quite young, that was tough down there, but I got through it with the support of my family and friends."

Vazzoler approached his recovery with a simple goal in mind and returned to the field for the Bega Roosters last season.

Cameron Vazzoler has returned to the game after recovering from a serious autoimmune disease. (ABC Illawarra: Tallon Smith)

"[It] took time and a lot of hard work, but I'm just grateful to be where I'm at now," he said.

Coach praises recovery

Three years after his diagnosis, Vazzoler is back at his old club in Kiama, and eyeing another premiership.

Kiama first grade coach Matt O'Brien said it was pleasing to see his playmaker back on the field.

Vazzoler's Kiama Knights are second on the Group 7 ladder. (ABC Illawarra: Tallon Smith)

"I think firstly it's just good to see him back happy and healthy, regardless of how he is playing at the moment, he seems pretty settled [and] enjoying it, that's probably the main thing," O'Brien said.

"If it's something you have done all your life and you've had a lot of success doing … to have that taken away from you, I would imagine would fuel even more competitiveness in him to get back being at a level where he's able to enjoy it.

"Footy's always been a part of his life, and this is a new chapter of it."

title: Burswood racetrack row deepens amid public feedback 'spin' accusations
text:
A community group has accused the WA Government of "spinning" the results of public feedback on a proposed community hub and racetrack in Burswood, contradicting the government's claims it has "significant" public support.

The $217 million development is set to include a 20,000-seat music bowl, function centre and motorsport circuit at Burswood Park and was a pre-election commitment.

A press release marking the end of the first part of the public consultation period claimed "76 per cent of all contributions provided positive ideas towards the project".

But Save Burswood Park Alliance co-chair Dr Robyn Harvey said that was a disingenuous framing of the data.

She said the feedback form offered no option for rejecting the development, instead asking for ideas.

Robyn Harvey said the results were not an accurate reflection of community sentiment. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"The online feedback did not allow you to simply say 'no' … so [the public] were saying things like 'more trees', 'look after the wildlife', 'we want an urban forest'," Dr Harvey said.

"So yes, there were lots of positive comments, but they certainly didn't feed into the idea that we wanted a motor racing track.

" They're spinning it. "

She said data collected by her group suggested an overwhelming majority of people were against the new development.

Some of the feedback provided during the community drop-in sessions. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"We took photographic evidence and screenshots of the online and drop-in feedback every day … 85 per cent of respondents on the online feedback said 'no racetrack'," she said.

" At the drop-in centres it was even more, it was 98 per cent of post-it notes said 'no racetrack'. "

According to the government's Perth Entertainment and Sporting Precinct report, there were 672 contributions via the online consultation platform.

The state government said the racetrack would only be used once a year. (Supplied: WA Labor)

"In summary, stakeholders offered significant support for the PESP with the majority recognising opportunity for their industry, association or group and identifying with the wider vision for the precinct," the report said.

"Opposition to the development centred around the use of the precinct for motorsport."

Response 'quite positive'

'Rita's racetrack' divides opinion Photo shows WA Premier Roger Cook smiles as he sits in a racing car. The WA government's controversial $217 million plan to build a street motorsport circuit at Perth's Burswood Park has incurred the wrath of many — and don't dare call it a motorplex.

Parliamentary secretary to the Premier, Daniel Pastorelli, who has been involved in community drop-in sessions about the proposal, said the "positive ideas" received complemented the government's proposal.

These included support for more hospitality venues, an urban forest and more trees.

"Things like more hospitality venues on the peninsula, things like an urban forest, people definitely want more trees in the park area," Mr Pastorelli told ABC Radio Perth.

" Overall, the response that we've received has been quite positive. "

"Obviously, some of the local residents are concerned about the motorsport element of the project, there's no doubt about that, and we understand that completely."

Mr Pastorelli said initial public concerns about the project were due to "misconceptions" the motorsport track would be used frequently, but he said it would only host a "one-off annual event".

The proposal has faced pushback from residents and advocates of green space, and from the WA Liberal leader Basil Zempilas, who has previously labelled the project a "wasteful" use of taxpayer dollars.

Basil Zempilas described the proposal as "wasteful". (ABC News: Phoebe Pin)

Dr Harvey said she was opposed to the destruction of an inner-city green space.

"Even if they're not racing on it [the race track], it destroys the park," she said.

" The urban forest that they suggest is something they will look at, there is no room for it, where will it go? "

But Mr Pastorelli insisted the consultation had been "a constructive process" with many ideas advanced "that may be added to the project as we progress".

A submission for the project is due to be made to the Environmental Protection Authority in coming weeks, and site investigations were underway.

title: Long road back for Tasmanian Labor under Willie must start now
text:
Listening to Labor Leader Josh Willie's first media interviews, you'd be forgiven for thinking little had changed.

Jobs are the main item of the day, he does not want to budge on salmon or greyhound industries — and he's still keen on the controversial Macquarie Point stadium.

But there are subtle shifts in his language that suggest a change in the party's direction.

Who is Josh Willie, new leader of Tasmanian Labor Photo shows A man smiling in a suit, walking into a room full of people. Joshua Barton Willie, a 41-year-old former primary school teacher, is the new leader of Tasmanian Labor — tasked with trying to engineer a party comeback after yet another election loss to the Liberals.

Firstly, the number of times Mr Willie said something along the lines of "we've just had one of the worst results in our history".

Until now, Labor has barely acknowledged how badly it lost the last election. Rather than taking a look in the mirror, it picked back up and decided to have another shot at government.

This time, instead of trying to woo voters, Labor set its eyes on the crossbench.

The result was the same — a resounding rejection.

Mr Willie knows that, and he wants Tasmanians to know he knows.

After all, you can't be serious about changing if you're not acknowledging there is a problem.

Josh Willie (standing) has been careful not to criticise his predecessor Dean Winter (seated at left). (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

For the record, in his first interview since losing the leadership, Dean Winter said he took "full responsibility" for the outcome of the election, acknowledging it wasn't good enough.

But back to Mr Willie.

New Labor leader Josh Willie outlines party vision Photo shows A man and a woman in an outdoor environment. New Labor Leader Josh Willie says his party needs to "pause and reflect" on its historically bad election result and "do the hard work to earn Tasmanians' trust".

He might not have gone as far to suggest that the first no-confidence vote — that ultimately led to an early election and Mr Winter's demise — was a mistake.

But when asked if it was a mistake, he simply said, "there is no shortcut to government".

A lot could be read into the lack of defence.

He gave that same answer when asked if he would move another no-confidence motion.

While he might not be ruling it out, it seems that one is not on the cards anytime soon.

Was Labor Liberal-lite?

So, where does Mr Willie think Labor went so wrong?

While he has been careful not to criticise his predecessor, Mr Willie was quick to say the party needs to "differentiate ourselves from the Liberals".

Tasmanians weren't ready for this election. Neither were their leaders Photo shows Two men at press conferences wear suits and stand outside. With the fourth election in seven years almost upon Tasmania, one thing is certain — more is needed from politicians to ensure good government is the norm, not the exception.

It is a criticism that was thrown at Dean Winter's Labor by the crossbench; that it is Liberal-lite, that it was just backing in the Liberals and it was the crossbench that was the "true opposition".

These criticisms were largely related to the party's support of the stadium.

The crossbench appeared to overlook the fact it was Labor that introduced industrial manslaughter laws and backed in various pieces of Greens' legislation.

Still, it seems Mr Willie may feel some of that criticism is warranted.

"We need to do the policy work to present a viable alternative that is different to the Liberals," he said.

" There is a lot of work to be done there. "

Mr Willie has flagged a return to focusing on Labor's traditional core issues such as health, housing, cost of living and education. (ABC News: Luke Bowden )

Jobs, jobs, jobs

Labor, under Mr Winter, reasserted itself as the party of jobs; something Mr Willie said was the right thing to do.

It spent most of the time talking about said jobs, the economy and the Spirit of Tasmania debacle.

The latter was a true triumph. Labor deserves all due credit for uncovering one of the state's biggest infrastructure stuff-ups and keeping the government accountable.

Labor targeted the government over its handling of the Spirit ships replacement project, but it wasn't enough to sway voters. (Supplied: TT-Line)

Those jobs it talked about, though, were jobs in the mining industry, salmon, forestry, construction, etc, echoing 1960s-era Labor.

That is something Mr Willie has acknowledged without quite being that harsh.

He has been careful to say that, yes, Labor does stand for "traditional" jobs, but it is the party for all workers.

"We need to make sure we're doing both," he said.

"We can talk about the economy, the opportunities, we can recognise the Tasmanians who are contributing in their jobs across the economy and we've always supported traditional industries. That's not going to change.

"But there are many people in service industries, in healthcare, education or people working in our Tasmanian success story, which is tourism and hospitality or new industries like startup and IT.

"You'll see me talking a lot across the economy and recognising the contributions of Tasmanians."

Mr Willie also seems aware that until the election, Labor spent little time talking about its core issues of health, housing, cost of living and education, only to try and reclaim them during the election.

The fact he has been regularly bringing those areas up as things he wants to focus on suggests he's aware they did not get the love they needed until too late.

Independent Kristie Johnston (centre) was scathing of Labor's unwillingness to work with the crossbench. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

A will to work with the crossbench

After Labor successfully passed its bill to introduce Industrial Manslaughter Laws last year — against the Liberal government's wishes — it seemed like the floodgates might open.

There was a world in which Labor, and a largely progressive crossbench, combined to bring in a lot of their own legislation. It is worth noting, some won't view this as ideal given their limited resources.

But Mr Winter was very clear that he did not want to govern from opposition.

Crossbenchers Peter George and Craig Garland also spoke of their frustrations with Dean Winter-led Labor's intransigence. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Minority Tasmanian Liberals watch on as Greens, Labor get bills up Photo shows A man with grey hair seated in parliament looks sad Chinks in Tasmania's minority government armour are appearing, as The Greens and Labor passed two consecutive bills through the lower house against the government's wishes.

Industrial manslaughter was the last Labor bill the 51st parliament saw, although Labor did go on to support several pieces of Greens legislation.

Mr Willie has pointed out that by refusing to support its motion of no confidence in Liberal Premier Jeremy Rockliff — and confidence in Labor's Dean Winter — it chose a Liberal government by default and they "have to take some ownership".

However, he also said there were opportunities to collaborate with the crossbench on issues where they have common ground. Pointing to integrity and transparency, in particular.

It seems whether the Liberals want it or not a stronger Integrity Commission might be on the way. Though the problem of funding is one only the government can address.

There is certainly an argument for not "governing from opposition".

There's also the limited resources and lack of access to treasury.

In the previous parliament, Mr Willie was tasked with attacking the Liberals' budgets. (ABC News: Jake Grant)

Another argument is the risk the public might feel they can have it both ways, with the Liberals in charge and Labor still getting progressive reforms through.

On the other hand, if Labor is trying to reassert itself as more progressive than the Liberals who passed a few pieces of progressive legislation that they were not so keen on, it may serve as a reminder that (greyhounds and salmon aside) Labor's core values are far more progressive than the Liberals.

Even under Mr Rockliff.

Finding a way to win back the voters

Loading...

On his first day out as leader, Mr Willie said Labor needed to "pause and reflect" to understand why people aren't voting for them.

So, don't expect the party to be rushing out with new policies any time soon.

Some people might be after a more drastic shift.

Maybe that will happen in time, but if it's serious about earning back the trust of Tasmanians, it would do better to take stock, listen and learn, to make sure those shifts are the right ones.

The election result alone shows there are a lot of lessons to be learnt.

Labor did learn and change after the 2024 election, but it seems that change was not the one the electorate wanted.

Forestry remains a contentious issue in Tasmania. (Supplied)

Stuck between traditional industries and voters who would like to see the end of things, like native forestry and greyhound racing, the party is always going to have a tough time.

But while majority government may not be in its future any time soon — given Hare-Clark and the many progressive independents and parties eating into its vote — it should be able to improve and pick up seats.

This time around, it seems, Labor wants to play the long game.

It will once again try to redefine who it is, but maybe after getting it a little wrong for far too long, the party will find that sweet spot and get it right.

For now though, what right is, is unclear.

That's up to Mr Willie to figure out.

title: Demand for truffles continues to climb despite $3,500 per kilo price tag
text:
There is no doubt that truffles can be expensive, selling for up to $3,500 per kilogram.

But the price has not put customers off, with producers experiencing heavy demand this season.

The rare fungus that grows among the roots of certain trees is prized by chefs worldwide for its distinctively earthy, musky aroma and rich umami flavour.

They are usually sold by the gram and typically shaved paper-thin over dishes like pasta, risotto and eggs.

Anthea Harrison and truffle-sniffing dog Odin look for truffles on their farm near Mount Gambier. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

Despite their black lumpy appearance, growers say their expense comes from their rarity and limited fruiting season.

'Every truffle is a miracle'

Anthea Harrison has grown black truffles at Echo Farm on the outskirts of Mount Gambier for the past three seasons.

While the first two seasons were fruitful, ongoing dry conditions across South Australia this year have resulted in truffles being harder to find.

"Every truffle is a miracle … and it's times like this that make you really appreciate that miracle," Ms Harrison said.

She said truffles required a delicate balance of factors to grow, including good-quality soil, warm summers, cold winters, and the right amount of rain and winter frost.

Anthea Harrison checks her orchard's soil for the scent of truffles. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

And even then, the fungi can still be temperamental.

"A farmer can put their heart and soul, and they usually do, into preparing the orchard and doing everything right … and even when you do all that, there is no guarantee," Ms Harrison said.

The business has not unearthed enough truffles this season to sell and will need to rely on profits from the previous year, along with other business activities, to get by.

"If there's any takeaway from this year it's that the price of truffle is justified," Ms Harrison said.

Pricing truffles

While they are a sought-after delicacy, the luxury produce is also priced at a premium due to the high overhead involved.

It is also a costly business to get into, which limits the supply of truffles, according to truffle grader and expert Simon Friend.

Manufactured truffle flavour 'misleading' Photo shows A man and woman hold dogs in their arms As demand for truffle flavour grows, the industry fears most people are not getting the real deal.

"The pricing of truffles in the world today is predicated largely by supply and demand," he said.

Initial costs can enter the hundreds of thousands of dollars to buy inoculated trees and prepare the soil, often with many tonnes of agricultural lime.

Ongoing management is also costly, with close and regular management required throughout the year.

And you cannot find any truffles without a specially-trained truffle-sniffing dog, which can cost up to $30,000.

Echo Farm saved money on hiring or buying a truffle dog by training their resident dog Odin to sniff out the treasures. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

"The capital outlay is significant before you even think about getting your first truffle," Mr Friend said.

The high overheads, combined with the aroma, freshness, size and taste of the produce, are what Mr Friend considers when pricing truffles.

They are best used within days after being purchased before they lose their quality.

"They are worth their price because they're unique and they're fleeting," he said.

Strong demand

Adelaide Hills truffle farmer and Australian Truffle Industry Association president Katherine Faull said, unlike Ms Harrison, she had experienced a more successful season, even harvesting a record crop.

The most commonly grown truffle in Australia is the French Black variety grown in WA, SA, Vic, Tas, NSW and the ACT. (ABC Central West: Emily Middleton)

Due to South Australia's ongoing drought conditions, Ms Faull's orchard relied on precision monitoring and irrigation this season.

Despite premium prices for buyers, Ms Faull said demand for her truffles had been "through the roof".

"We have, to an extent, struggled to keep up with demand," she said.

"It's becoming more common for South Australian chefs to put truffle on their menu because they know that they can source truffles locally now, which is really exciting."

title: In a male teacher drought, Ryan is an endangered breed
text:
Ryan Brown never saw primary school teaching as even a remote career path, but now believes he's found his "calling".

"I can't express how fun it is, how rewarding it is," he said.

"I've found something I'll do for the rest of my life, and having done a bunch of other jobs, I'm so glad I found it."

But Mr Brown is a rare breed — one of just two male classroom teachers at his Canberra primary school.

For the majority of his Year 5 students, it's the first time they have ever been taught by a man.

For many of his students Ryan Brown is the first male teacher they've ever had. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

"This is not an easy option for a job as a male — you really have to be able to relate to children … and I think sometimes men struggle to be vulnerable," he said.

The proportion of male educators in Australia has been falling for decades.

Men now represent just 17.6 per cent of primary school teaching staff, and 38.5 per cent of high school teachers.

Without steps to remedy the disparity, researchers say those numbers will continue to dwindle.

What's driving the decline?

Education researcher Kevin McGrath from the Australian Catholic University said the declining trend was the result of two key forces.

"Firstly, there is a large economic factor, and that is, on average and compared to women, men can earn more in other industries," Dr McGrath said.

"Second, there are social expectations around who belongs in the teaching profession — teaching is often associated with stereotypical traits of being caring and nurturing."

Ryan Brown says teaching can be a challenging job for men if they struggle being vulnerable. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

And there are fears that recent explosive allegations of abuse within the childcare sector will also act as a deterrent for male educators.

"A female teacher can hug their students for comfort," Mr Brown said.

"[In my class] you're not allowed to hug Mr Brown — high-fives only.

"The relationships are different."

Men now represent just 17.6 per cent of primary school teaching staff, and 38.5 per cent of high school teachers. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

Associate Professor Matthew Brown from the University of Canberra's education faculty said the pervasive undervaluing of teachers also played a major part.

"If you've got society basically not rewarding and not recognising the value of teaching as a profession, then young people, men, boys, will be thinking, 'Well, I'll go into another profession'," he said.

That rings true for Ben Weir, who is accustomed to people questioning his decision to become a high school maths and science teacher.

"Particularly to men … [it's seen as] a lesser career, one that you're choosing by sacrificing other careers you could be having," the Canberra student said.

Teaching student Ben Weir says he's used to people asking why he decided to become a high school maths and science teacher. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

"That was really something that was prominent in my undergraduate degree — 'you have all this potential and you're only using it to teach'."

Why we should care

Experts agree that having more diversity in the classroom benefits both students and staff.

As schools grapple with staff shortages, Dr McGrath said finding ways to attract more men into the profession should be part of the solution.

"It's unlikely that we can address the teacher shortage that we experience here in Australia while such a significant portion of the population fails to see teaching as a suitable career choice," he said.

Dr Kevin McGrath says attracting more men to teaching should be part of the solution to school staff shortages. (ABC News: Simon Avery)

He said Australia's failure to address the decline of male teachers was a glaring gap in its gender equality goals.

"Boys and girls have both told us in research that they would like to be taught by both men and women," Dr McGrath said.

"For boys, it's important that they see teachers who they perceive understand them.

"For girls … they tell us that having male teachers is important for them because the absence of male teachers actually contributes to their anxieties around interacting with men more broadly."

He said research also showed job satisfaction among female teachers was higher in schools with a greater gender balance.

Associate Professor Brown says the pervasive undervaluing of teachers plays a major part in the male teacher shortage. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

Associate Professor Brown said it was important for students to be exposed to more men in both caring and leadership roles.

"We need more men in the teaching workforce so that we can allow children and young people to see positive role models for men," he said.

Can the trend be reversed?

Dr McGrath said a range of initiatives to attract men to teaching, including scholarships and gender targets, had been floated or trialled over the years.

"These have either been blocked by union groups or dropped when there has been no progress or no quick wins that have been made," he said.

He said it was time to revisit those ideas — and commit to them long-term.

"Scholarships for people considering a career in teaching are actually the single most effective recruitment initiative that we could use," he said.

In a statement, Australian Education Union president Correna Haythorpe said the union supported scholarships, placements and development opportunities for "all aspiring teachers".

Australian Education Union president Correna Haythorpe says the union supports scholarships, placements and development opportunities for "all aspiring teachers". (ABC News: Sean Warren)

"We have a teacher shortage crisis and fixing the underlying issues in the profession is the best way to improve diversity and bring more men, and more people generally, into teaching," Ms Haythorpe said.

"Reducing excessive workloads, ensuring competitive pay and conditions, providing high-quality professional development, and guaranteeing appropriate mentoring and career support are some of the changes that will encourage more people — including men — to consider teaching as a long-term career."

Associate Professor Brown said there was no quick fix to increasing the number of male teachers, but said reframing the conversation was essential.

Associate Professor Brown says there's no quick fix to resolve the male teacher shortage. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

"This particular problem took decades to create and it's going to take some time, possibly decades, to repair," he said.

"If we value teaching, men will come back to teaching.

"It's not that we need fewer women — we need the same number of women, if not more women. And now we need more men."

Ryan Brown says the shortage of male educators means boys are less likely to see teaching as a potential career path for their future. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

'Maybe I would have found it sooner'

Back in the classroom, Ryan Brown said his situation was a simple case of you cannot be what you cannot see.

"It took me so long to figure out I wanted to be a teacher, whereas if it had been more common or if more people had stated this was an option for me, maybe I would have found it sooner," he said.

"Some of my students — and it's very sweet — talk about how they want to be teachers, and I don't know if the boys would've said that before they had me as a teacher."

Teaching student Ben Weir says he's eager to start his full-time teaching career. (ABC News: Lily Nothling)

Ben Weir is eager to start working in the classroom full-time next year as he completes his teaching program.

"Through the work I'm doing as a learning support assistant, you're really seeing how a male role model for these students is really important," he said.

"[I want to be] someone they can talk to and relate to and see how being a male in a community or a society, you should really conduct yourself and treat others."

title: Jonassen creates cricket history with power-hitting display in The Hundred
text:
Jess Jonassen has produced a sensational display of six-hitting, the Australian all-rounder becoming the first woman to hit four maximums in a single five-ball "over" in England's premier white-ball competition, The Hundred.

With a supreme all-round display, as she also snaffled three wickets with her spin, the player-of-the-match heroics from Jonassen also finally gifted the struggling Welsh Fire their first win of the campaign and ended the hopes of Ellyse Perry's Birmingham Phoenix to reach the play-offs.

Fellow Aussie star Perry finally found some form after a disappointing campaign by her lofty standards as she fired her first half-century of the tournament, but it was nowhere near enough to eclipse the brilliance of 32-year-old Jonassen, whose 44 off 17 deliveries and 3-24 off 20 balls set up the Fire's 36-run win.

Jonassen has lost her place in the international team but has shown in the Fire's last two matches just why she is still such a force in the women's game with her big hitting and crafty bowling.

Her big moment came with 10 balls left of the Fire's innings when she took a fancy to the spin of Hannah Baker.

After Hayley Matthews (34 not out) had taken a single off the first of the five-ball set, the Australian clouted the next four for sixes, the first two of which saw her nearly caught on the boundary.

The 25 runs off Baker's set was a record in the women's Hundred.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"Can't say I'd be on the top of anyone's list to achieve that," smiled Jonassen of her landmark feat, though those who watched her clean hitting for Brisbane Heat in their WBBL final near-miss might beg to differ.

"Not too bad to be fair. I got a little bit of luck with the bat, kind of muscled a few, but I'm really pleased we finally got some points on the board," she added, reflecting on her narrow escapes.

"I just really wanted to take the game on, particularly in those last 10 balls — and it doesn't matter how far over the rope they go!"

Another Australian international, Megan Schutt, finally got her out but Jonassen's late impetus, with three fours to go with her quartet of sixes, dragged the Fire to 3-150 after Sophia Dunkley had kicked off their innings with a half-century.

Perry's Phoenix had to win to keep their tournament hopes alive but Jonassen struck the key blow to bamboozle and bowl her charging compatriot Georgia Voll, who had raced to 29 off 18 balls.

Perry had to effectively play a lone hand with her 55 off 43 balls, featuring seven fours and a six, but it proved to be in vain.

The defeat sent Phoenix to the bottom of the table as the Fire leapfrogged them. "She's been amazing the last couple of games — with 4-10 in her last game nearly dragging us back into it, and now such a great show of hitting," said Fire captain Tammy Beaumont of Jonassen's display.

AAP

title: 'Deliver it now': Outer suburbs councils call for new stations to ease choked roads
text:
The mayor of an outer Melbourne community is calling on the state government to urgently fund a train station in his growing community, where just 1.2 per cent of people regularly catch public transport.

Beveridge, at the northern edge of Melbourne’s growth boundary, is set to boom.

Council data shows the area is already home to about 11,000 people, and that's expected to double in the next five years.

Earlier this month, the state government also approved plans for a new suburb, Beveridge North West, which will see a further 47,000 residents move in by 2052.

But Mitchell Shire Mayor, John Dougall, is scathing of the level of infrastructure investment he sees from the state government to support his growing community.

"We’re still waiting for the basics," he told a forum of Outer Melbourne Councils in South Morang.

Council data shows just 1.2 per cent of people who live in Beveridge catch public transport.

"And it’s not because they don’t want to, it’s because they can't," he said.

He urged the state government to fund a train station at Beveridge, where the Seymour Vline train passes land that is "shovel-ready" for the station.

"This is our chance to get it right," he said, urging the state government to build the station now, before more residents move in.

Beveridge resident Scott Reid says he doesn't trust public transport to get him to work on time. (Supplied)

"Beveridge station is a test: deliver it now, not in 10 to 15 years," he said.

Scott Reid is one of the 98.8 per cent of Beveridge residents who don’t regularly use public transport.

"I try to avoid PT like the plague just because I’ve heard far too many stories about services being cancelled," he said.

He said the daily commute to work in Clifton Hill takes about 40 minutes if there’s no traffic, but it can take up to an hour and a half, if the Hume Freeway is busy.

"We’re funnelling people into a car park," he said.

He recently went to pick up the kids from school, but got stuck in traffic at the freeway overpass.

"It took me half an hour to go 2 kilometres," he said.

"I was fuming. I could walk faster."

He said the state government should fund a train station in Beveridge, to give people options.

"It’s well and truly overdue, having a decent method for myself and my kids to get in and out of the city, in and out of Wallan, proper infrastructure in place," he said.

Once developed, Beveridge North West is expected to add 47,000 residents to the region. (ABC News: Kyle Harley)

Calls to improve outer suburban public transport

Congested roads and a lack of reliable public transport options were common themes of the meeting of Outer Melbourne Councils in South Morang, in Melbourne’s outer north.

Mayor of the Yarra Ranges Shire, in the outer east, Jim Childs, called on the government to build an extra train station between Mooroolbark and Lilydale, where a new development at Kinley will create an extra 3,000 homes.

That would mean duplicating the tracks between the two existing stations, which were first built in the 1890s.

"We’ve got to get this infrastructure correct," Cr Childs said.

"The infrastructure is not there to get all the cars off the roads."

Population boom puts pressure on transport

In the city’s west, Melton is the fastest-growing local government area in Australia, with an annual growth rate of 6.5 per cent, well above the state average of 1.9 per cent.

The council’s manager of city strategy, Travis Conway, said access and transport is the number one issue people raise with the council.

"We have a population growing day by day, and using largely one road – the Western Highway," he said.

That was illustrated this week in Thornhill Park, where a road upgrade means the only local road connecting the community to high schools and the train station will be shut until December – forcing locals onto the freeway for every school drop-off and pick-up, adding up to 45 minutes each way.

Just to the south, Wyndham’s population is growing at 4.3 per cent a year, making it the sixth fastest growing area in Australia.

Dean Ellis, Wyndham’s coordinator of transport planning, said electrifying the train line should be a priority, so commuters aren’t relying on Vline diesel trains.

"Six-to-nine car trains don't cut it when it comes to growth corridors," he said.

He pointed out Tarneit train station is the second-busiest Vline station in Victoria, with nearly 1.5 million annual entries.

Melbourne’s Southern Cross tops the list with nearly 6 million entries, while Geelong station recorded 969,600 annual entries.

"People can't get on the train," he said.

In Melbourne’s north-east, Nillumbik Shire is not predicted to grow as much as other outer councils, but mayor John Dumaresq said the area still struggles with access to transport, particularly buses.

"Right now, transport gaps are closing down peoples' lives," he said.

He said increasing access to public transport, particularly for young people and the elderly, is critical to connecting communities and keeping roads free from congestion.

"There's thousands of trips being made in cars that don't need to be made," he said.

Mitchell Shire Mayor, John Dougall, says his community would catch public transport if it was available.

President of the Public Transport Users Association, Tony Morton, said increasing the frequency of bus services is critical.

"We have a lot of examples of lines on a map for bus lines that sometimes only come every hour or every half-hour," he said.

"That's when you get people looking at the service and saying, 'this is not providing a viable alternative to my car'."

Parliamentary Secretary for Transport, Josh Bull, told the forum the government is delivering "a long list of projects" that will help ease congestion in Melbourne, including the Metro Rail Tunnel, due to open later this year.

"It’s about unlocking a rapidly growing city and state," he said.

He added big projects, like the Suburban Rail Loop, take time.

"I wouldn't want to be standing here in 30 years' time and saying, 'if only we'd done that'," he said.

The opposition's Richard Welch said Victoria is "already behind schedule" when it comes to infrastructure planning.

"The population is growing on the fringes, and you do not have the infrastructure," he said.

Back in Beveridge, John Dougall said the community is still angry the state government approved a quarry as part of the new precinct structure plan.

He said, along with a new sports field, a train station would be one way to give back to the community.

"The quarry has pushed the community in Beveridge to the edge," he said.

"For us, Beveridge train station would be an appropriate return for underpinning that infrastructure development."

The ABC has contacted the Victorian government for comment.

title: Stirring scenes as Aussie qualifier Aiava books US Open spot in thriller
text:
Destanee Aiava's breakthrough tennis year has reached another peak, with the battling Australian making it through US Open qualifying, ensuring she will play in the main draw for the second year in a row.

While teenage hope Emerson Jones again found the going too hot in her final-round qualifying match at Flushing Meadows, 25-year-old Melburnian Aiava came through a deciding match tiebreak to defeat rising German Emma Seidel 5-7, 6-1, 7-6 (10-6).

In an absorbing two-and-a-half-hour duel, Aiava was left emotional after making it to her third grand slam of the year.

She was up against it in her third match of the week, facing the 20-year-old world number 105 Seidel, who was 63 places higher on the WTA computer and looked poised to confirm her rankings superiority after taking the first set.

But Aiava responded to reel off five straight games to take the second set and, when the decider proved a tight affair, she twice served successfully to stay in the match.

Aiava then held her nerve better in the decisive first-to-10-points breaker, serving down her 10th ace before Seidel double-faulted to gift her third three-set victory of the week.

It was another hugely encouraging moment for the woman who had earned such admiration in Melbourne in January when she talked of how she had to battle with borderline personality disorder (BPD) on her way to her best-ever grand-slam display.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

She eventually bowed out in the second round there after giving feisty 10th seed Danielle Collins plenty of trouble in another three-setter.

Earlier, 17-year-old Jones, who had also failed to get through the final round of qualifying at Wimbledon, had found Andorran world number 132 Victoria Jiménez Kasintseva too tough a hurdle as she succumbed 7-5, 7-6 (9-7).

The Gold Coast youngster, currently the world's number two junior and now up to 199 in the rankings, had her chances, having led 5-3 in the opening stanza before also battling back to earn four set points in the second-set breaker.

But the 20-year-old Andorra held tough to win from 6-3 down in the breaker.

Priscilla Hon also advanced to the main draw, defeating Belgium's Hanne Vanderwinkel 6-3, 6-3. However, James Duckworth and Jason Kubler were both eliminated.

AAP

title: No, you’re not imagining it. That round shiny thing in the sky is the sun
text:
There’s a saying, mostly attributed to the Germans, that goes “there’s no such thing as bad weather, just inappropriate clothing”.

I was contemplating this last week when, in my harried preparations to leave the house for the office, I reached for my gumboots. “Ha,” I thought, “I’ve got this wet weather thing sorted.”

Like most Sydneysiders, I’m glad to see the back of this “rain event” which, the Bureau of Meteorology reports, has resulted in four or five times the usual dump of water for this time of year. Instead of an average of 80 millimetres for the month, we’ve had 370 millimetres as of last Friday. It’s a relief to see the sun.

Fun in the sun on Bondi Beach as the rainy weather lifts on Saturday. Credit: Flavio Brancaleone

Senior bureau meteorologist Angus Hines says we’re in for a week of clear, sunny skies. Rather than rain, though, it will be windy.

title: How to have a 5 star Saturday like Shelley Craft
text:
I love the buzz of The Block life and the thrill of live events, but when I’m off the clock, I’m all in on quality time. There are no cameras and no call sheets, but there’s still plenty to fill my cup, like delicious family dinners out on the town or a restorative girls’ trip up the coast.

There’s a lot of power in saying “no”, says Shelley.

While the rest of the household appreciates a sleep-in, my two Rhodesian ridgebacks don’t know Saturday from Tuesday, so it’s still an early start for me. I’ll go for a walk before 7am and then head home for a sauna and ice bath. I really like to savour the start of my Saturday. Even if the day ends up full, those first few mindful minutes — whether it’s a quiet coffee, some journaling or just standing in the morning sun — make all the difference.

Find what fuels you

Although my morning is structured, the afternoon is totally freestyle. If the sun’s out, we’re outside enjoying the beach, the backyard, our bikes — whatever. After a week of schedules, it’s important to let the day unfold.

title: Can the Wallabies beat South Africa again? Yes – if they do these five things
text:
While last week’s historic win at Ellis Park was followed by Wallabies scarves and jerseys being pulled out from cupboards across the country, every Australian rugby fan is bracing for a Springboks response in Cape Town this weekend after a performance in Johannesburg labelled as “dogshit” by coach Rassie Erasmus.

History suggests the Wallabies face an even greater challenge on Saturday (kick-off 1:10am Sunday, AEST). The last time they recorded back-to-back wins over the Springboks was Brisbane (2021) and the Gold Coast (2022).

The Wallabies haven’t beaten the Springboks twice in South Africa in a calendar year since 1963. The last time Australia opened a Rugby Championship campaign with two straight wins was in 2015.

As for back-to-back away victories in the tournament? You have to go back to 2000 (Wellington and Durban), when John Eales was captain.

title: Why a Wallaroos star didn’t tell her parents she was debuting for Australia
text:
Adiana Talakai’s dad Petani was always her biggest supporter, but there was a time when she didn’t want him at her games. Specifically, the day Talakai made her debut for the Australian women’s rugby side, the Wallaroos, in a Test match in 2022.

For reasons she now struggles to explain, the NSW hooker decided she wouldn’t tell her father - and her whole family - that she’d been picked to play for the Wallaroos against Fiji in Brisbane. It’s just a camp, she fibbed.

“I was scared that I was going to waste their time,” Talakai said. “I value what my parents have put into me. So I didn’t want to waste any more time and sacrifice that they have to. I didn’t want to disappoint them.

“And yes, it was the dumbest thing I’ve ever done in my entire life.”
